facts: The word “theater” comes from a Greek word meaning “a place for viewing,” because audiences gathered to watch stories acted out live.
Ancient Greek theaters were often built into hillsides so thousands of people could see and hear without microphones.
In Shakespeare’s time, many female roles were played by boys because women were not allowed to perform on some English stages.
A “script” is the written plan for a play, including the dialogue and often stage directions that tell actors where to move.
Stage directions like “upstage” and “downstage” come from old stages that were slanted, making the back higher than the front.
Costume and set designers use color, texture, and shapes to help show a character’s personality and the time period of the story.
A “curtain call” happens at the end of a show when actors return to the stage to thank the audience for their applause.
sources_hint: Common theater history references include textbooks and museum/encyclopedia overviews such as Britannica, the Victoria and Albert Museum Theatre & Performance collections, and Shakespeare’s Globe educational resources.
